discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
AC is correct
B is using the wrong data type for variable y
D is missing a return clause
E is inserting into an IN variable

comments.content: AC are the right answers; It wouldnt work if you dont use USING clause because there is a bind variable called ":b"

discussion.content: AC is working without Using Clause

choices.B: CREATE PROCEDURE p1 (y IN OUT pkg.tab_typ) IS BEGIN EXECUTE IMMEDIATE SELECT f (:b) FROM DUAL INTO y USING pkg.x; END p1;
choices.C: CREATE PROCEDURE p2 (v IN OUT VARCHAR2) IS BEGIN EXECUTE IMMEDIATE SELECT f (:b) FROM DUAL INTO v USING pkg.x; END p2;
choices.E: CREATE PROCEDURE p5 (y pkg. rec_typ) IS BEGIN EXECUTE IMMEDIATE SELECT pdt_name FROM TABLE (:b) BULK COLLECT INTO y USING pkg.x;
choices.D: CREATE FUNCTION p3 RETURN pkg. tab_typ IS BEGIN EXECUTE IMMEDIATE SELECT f (:b) FROM DUAL INTO pkg.x; END p3;
choices.A: CREATE FUNCTION p4 (y pkg.tab_typ) RETURN pkg.tab_typ IS BEGIN EXECUTE IMMEDIATE SELECT pdt_id, pdt_name FROM TABLE (:b) BULT COLLECT INTO pkg.x USING y; RETURN pkg.x; END p4;

choices.D: With the BEQUEATH CURRENT_USER clause, a definer’s rights function referenced in a view executes with the privileges of the view owner, not the function
choices.A: If a view references a PL/SQL function then BEQUEATH CURRENT_USER allows the function to execute with DBA privileges, regardless of the invoking users privileges.
choices.C: Any view calling a PL/SQL function with BEQUEATH CURRENT_USER in effect will execute with the privileges of the function owner.
choices.B: The BEQUEATH CURRENT_USER clause allows invoker’s rights functions referenced in a view to execute with the privileges of the invoking user.

comments.content:
-- AS Spider
 SELECT * 
 FROM HR.BEQUEATH_DEFINER_COUNT_ROWS_VIEW; --44 
 SELECT * 
 FROM HR.BEQUEATH_INVOKER_COUNT_ROWS_VIEW; --25 <-- since it has access only to COUNTRIES

-- AS Superman
 SELECT * 
 FROM HR.BEQUEATH_DEFINER_COUNT_ROWS_VIEW; --44 
 SELECT * 
 FROM HR.BEQUEATH_INVOKER_COUNT_ROWS_VIEW; --19 <-- since it has access only to JOBS

questions.question_text: Select the correct statement regarding BEQUEATH CURRENT_USER.
Which tablespace is used to store the data collected by PL/Scope?

discussion.content: PL/Scope stores the data that it collects in the SYSAUX tablespace. If the PL/Scope collection is enabled and SYSAUX tablespace is unavailable during compilation of a program unit, PL/Scope does not collect data for the compiled object. The compiler does not issue a warning, but it saves a warning in USER_ERRORS.

Correct answer is B: SYSAUX
Source: https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/appdev.111/b28424/adfns_plscope.htm#BABDGJAF

PL/Scope stores the data that it collects in the SYSAUX tablespace
A is the right answer based on the link you provide

A:
see here: ctrl F : Restrictions on Result-Cached Functions
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/appdev.111/b28370/subprograms.htm#g3335204

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

choices.D: The function must have an OUT or an IN OUT parameter.
choices.C: The function must be declared as a pipelined table function.
choices.A: The IN parameters must not include BLOB, CLOB, collection or record data types.
choices.B: The function must be created with invoker’s rights or in an anonymous block.

questions.question_text: Which must be true in order to add RESULT_CACHE to a function header and have it compile successfully?

discussion.content: DBMS_RLS.ADD_POLICY can implement fine-grained access control

Selected Answer: BC
BC is correct
C and D because the mask is in FGA and not Fine Grained Access Control https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B19306_01/network.102/b14266/apdvpoli.htm#i1008295

comments.content: Confirm, B and C are correct answers
I have to admit i was wrong. Column masking is possible so correct answers are B and C. DBMS_FGA is used for Fine Grained Auditing.

discussion.content: C and E are correct. You can't mask columns but lines by FGA
BC, not CD. The linked reference says you CAN use separate policies, not that you're REQUIRED to use separate policies.

choices.B: It can be used to implement column masking.
choices.A: It is implemented by end users.
choices.E: The DBMS_FGA package is used to set up fine-grained access control.
choices.D: Separate policies are required for queries versus INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE statements.
choices.C: It implements security rules through functions and associates these security rules with tables, views or synonyms.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true with respect to fine-grained access control?
